title: World's Best Scones! From Scotland to the Savoy to the U.S. Recipe
description: This is the best scone recipe! The addition of sour cream gives these a tender crumb. Serve them with clotted cream, butter, and a selection of jams.

From Scotland to the Savoy to the U.S. 4.7 (813) 685 Reviews 142 Photos In search of the best scone recipe, I have adapted my Scottish grandmother's recipe with my own touches and with the famous scone recipe from the world-renowned Savoy hotel in London. I now believe I have created the best scone recipe in the world! Serve with butter or clotted cream and a selection of jams. Submitted by FRIENDLYFOOD Updated on November 16, 2023 Save Rate Print Share Add Photo 142 142 142 142 Prep Time: 15 mins Cook Time: 10 mins Additional Time: 10 mins Total Time: 35 mins Servings: 8 Yield: 8 scones Jump to Nutrition Facts Cook Mode (Keep screen awake) Ingredients 1x 2x 4x Oops! Something went wrong. Our team is working on it. Original recipe (1X) yields 8 servings Scones: 1 ¾ cups all-purpose flour 4 teaspoons baking powder ¼ cup white sugar ⅛ teaspoon salt 5 tablespoons unsalted butter ½ cup dried currants ½ cup milk ¼ cup sour cream Egg Wash: 1 egg 1 tablespoon milk Directions Gather the ingredients. Preheat the oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C). Grease a baking sheet. Make the scones: Sift flour, baking powder, sugar, and salt into a large bowl. Cut in butter with a pastry blender or by rubbing between fingers until lumps are the size of peas. Stir in currants. Whisk milk and sour cream together in a measuring cup; gently stir into flour mixture until dough is moistened, being careful not to overwork the dough. With floured hands, pat dough into 2- to 3-inch diameter balls. Place onto the prepared baking sheet and flatten lightly. Scones should slightly touch each other. Make the egg wash: Whisk egg and milk together. Brush the tops of scones with egg wash and let them rest for about 10 minutes. Bake in the preheated oven until the tops are golden brown, 10 to 15 minutes. Recipe Tips You can use raisins instead of currants.Scones can be reheated by splitting them in half and toasting or wrapping them in aluminum foil and heating them in the oven. Add Your Photo Photos of World's Best Scones! From Scotland to the Savoy to the U.S. 01 of 142 Photo by  Allrecipes Member 02 of 142 Photo by  lsutts1213 04/04/2025 I followed the tweaks on Jay's review ... reduced baking powder. Increased butter to 6 tbsp and did not use egg wash added sugar on top ......they turned out excellent and I got several requests to remake them. Definitely a must keep recipe. Biggest takeaway do not overwork or handle the dough too much. 03 of 142 Photo by  StrongChip1639 04/11/2024 Easy to follow Great flavours and easy to make. I subsituted the sour cream for yoghurt. The kids loved it! 04 of 142 Photo by  Wanda Andreu 07/14/2021 05 of 142 Photo by  Tracy Tingley 02/01/2021 06 of 142 Photo by  Christine 08/16/2020 07 of 142 Photo by  REB 08/14/2020 08 of 142 Photo by  Mala 06/13/2020 09 of 142 Photo by  Mala 06/13/2020 10 of 142 Photo by  Amyrra Rais 06/06/2020 Hands down the best scones recipe ever! I also followed tips from Care to reduce the baking powder to 3 tsp and place it in the fridge after rubbing in the butter. It turned out great! But i kinda let it bake a few minutes more and it browned a bit on top but still delicious! A little bit crunchy top and soft on the inside.
